questions.text: An 18-year-old waiter comes for a follow-up of proteinuria. He also complains of swelling in his feet after standing all day. Urinalysis showed 500 mg of protein. However, a repeat sample taken on the next morning had no protein. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with proteinuria in a urine sample with a clean sample in the morning most likely has orthostatic proteinuria, which occurs due to his upright posture all day. 

Orthostatic proteinuria is the most common cause of isolated proteinuria in teenagers and children. It is believed to occur due to either a left renal vein entrapment or an exaggerated vascular response leading to increased filtration pressure in the kidneys. Family history should be obtained to rule out any familial conditions associated with proteinuria. 

Diagnosis and Management: Diagnosis is confirmed by obtaining a Urine protein to creatinine ratio in the standing and recumbent position and noting a difference between the two. 

Usually, asymptomatic patients need no further management. Annual followups are required to monitor for further worsening of the proteinuria.

Other options:

Option A: Minimal change disease is associated with >3g of protein excretion per day with edema and hypercholesterolemia. This patient does not meet the criteria for a diagnosis of MCD.

Option C: Sustained proteinuria is a term used to describe >1-2g/day of proteinuria and is associated with glomerular disease.

Option D: Transient proteinuria is seen in conditions like fever, exercise and emotional stress and has a benign prognosis.

questions.text: All of the following conditions cause overflow proteinuria except:
questions.solution:
Nephrolithiasis is an example of postrenal proteinuria which occurs due to an insult beyond the renal tubules. All the other given conditions cause proteinuria due to an increase in the production of a particular type of protein; light chains in multiple myeloma, myoglobin in rhabdomyolysis, and hemoglobin in intravascular hemolysis.

In the given scenario, the patient has multiple myeloma. Thus the type of proteinuria this patient is likely to have is overflow proteinuria.

Various types of proteinuria:

  • Glomerular - Increased filtration of proteins due to the disruption of the basement membrane
  • Tubular - Impaired protein reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) due to damage to the tubules 
  • Overflow - Excess production of low-molecular-weight proteins, such as light chains, in multiple myeloma
  • Postrenal - Secretion of IgA and IgG by the urinary tract due to infections or stones

Normally, the following mechanisms prevent proteinuria:

The glomerular basement membrane acts as a barrier to prevent the loss of negatively charged and large proteins.
Reabsorption of small proteins in the PCT

questions.text: A child presents with a distended abdomen after a history of frothy urine for the last 1 month. Fluid analysis shows a growth of Streptococcus pneumonia. Other investigations are normal except for an increase in serum cholesterol. What is the likely etiology of this infection?
questions.solution:
This child with a history of frothy urine for 3 weeks now presenting with ascites has a culture positive for Streptococcus pneumonia. This indicates peritonitis. The presence of hypercholesterolemia in combination with frothy urine raises suspicion of nephrotic syndrome.This leads to a loss of immunoglobulins in the urine which renders the child unable to mount an immune response making him susceptible to infections. 

Nephrotic syndrome in children is primarily idiopathic, with minimal change disease being the most common glomerular lesion. Podocyte injury or genetic mutations in podocyte proteins can lead to nephrotic-range proteinuria.

Edema is the most common presenting symptom. They have elevated levels of cholesterol, triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins (LDL), and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). It is caused by both increased lipid synthesis and decreased lipid catabolism. 

They are prone to infections especially by encapsulated bacteria due to factors such as urinary losses of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and complement factors (C3, C5, factors B and D). Nephrotic syndrome is a hypercoagulable state due to vascular stasis, increased platelet, increased hepatic production of fibrinogen, and urinary losses of antithrombotic factors such as antithrombin III and protein S. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by performing a urinalysis and urine protein: creatinine ratio. The recommended initial treatment for nephrotic syndrome is a daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) of prednisolone for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks. 

Definitions regarding the course of nephrotic syndrome: 

Remission is characterized by a urine protein: creatinine ratio of <0.2 or <1+ protein on urine dipstick testing for 3 consecutive days
Response in nephrotic syndrome is defined as achieving remission within the initial 4 weeks of corticosteroid therapy
Relapse is indicated by an increase in urine protein: creatinine ratio >0.2 or a reading of 2+ and higher for 3 consecutive days.
Frequently relapsing: ≥2 relapses in 6 months or 4 relapses in 12 months.
Steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome: Relapse during steroid tapering or within 2 weeks of discontinuation.
Steroid resistance: Failure to achieve remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone for 4 weeks and alternate days for the next 4 weeks.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy comes with complaints of fatigue and tiredness for 2 weeks. He consumes a balanced diet. He also has been having frothy urine for a few months. Further evaluation shows 7.2 mg/dl hemoglobin, normal serum eosinophil count, and 3.5 g of protein in the urine. Which of the following explains his anemia?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with nephrotic range proteinuria with complaints of fatigue most likely has developed anemia secondary to urinary protein losses. There is an increase in excretion of transferrin, (a protein responsible for carrying iron), iron, and other ions which lead to these patients being susceptible to iron deficiency anemia. 

Nephrotic syndrome in children is primarily idiopathic, with minimal change disease being the most common glomerular lesion. Podobcyte injury or genetic mutations in podocyte proteins can lead to nephrotic-range proteinuria.

Edema is the most common presenting symptom. They have elevated levels of cholesterol, triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins (LDL), and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). It is caused by both increased lipid synthesis and decreased lipid catabolism. 

They are prone to infections especially by encapsulated bacteria due to factors such as urinary losses of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and complement factors (C3, C5, factors B and D). Nephrotic syndrome is a hypercoagulable state due to vascular stasis, increased platelet, increased hepatic production of fibrinogen, and urinary losses of antithrombotic factors such as antithrombin III and protein S. Iron deficiency anemia is a rare sequelae and is associated with the steroid-resistant variant of nephrotic syndrome. Still, it can be present in children who have gone untreated for a long time. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by performing a urinalysis and urine protein: creatinine ratio. The recommended initial treatment for nephrotic syndrome is a daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) of prednisolone for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks. 

Definitions regarding the course of nephrotic syndrome: 

Remission is characterized by a urine protein: creatinine ratio of <0.2 or <1+ protein on urine dipstick testing for 3 consecutive days
Response in nephrotic syndrome is defined as achieving remission within the initial 4 weeks of corticosteroid therapy
Relapse is indicated by an increase in urine protein: creatinine ratio >0.2 or a reading of 2+ and higher for 3 consecutive days.
Frequently relapsing: ≥2 relapses in 6 months or 4 relapses in 12 months.
Steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome: Relapse during steroid tapering or within 2 weeks of discontinuation.
Steroid resistance: Failure to achieve remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone for 4 weeks and alternate days for the next 4 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following tests are done to evaluate protein in urine?
questions.solution:
Sulfosalicylic acid test is done to evaluate for protein in the urine. 

The sulfosalicylic acid (SSA) test is done by mixing one part of urine with three parts of SSA and then comparing the turbidity that develops according to the following:

  • 0: no turbidity (0 mg/dL)
  • Trace: slight turbidity (1 to 10 mg/dL)
  • 1+: turbidity through which print can be read (15 to 30 mg/dL)
  • 2+: white cloud without precipitate (40 to 100 mg/dL)
  • 3+: white cloud with fine precipitate (150 to 350 mg/dL)
  • 4+: flocculent precipitate (>500 mg/dL)

Other options: 

Options A and B: Moore's test and Seliwanoff's test are done to test to distinguish between monosaccharides and disaccharides. 

Option C: Muric acid test is done to test for galactose.

questions.text:
You are managing a patient with microalbuminuria. He has a past history of diabetes and hypertension. Which of the following drugs can be used as a part of his drug regimen ?
  1. Empagliflozin
  2. Losartan
  3. Amlodipine
  4. Chlorthalidone
  5. Lisinopril
questions.solution:
This patient with microalbuminuria with a past history of diabetes and hypertension will need a drug that can manage his comorbidities and prevent the worsening of his kidney function. Out of the options, empagliflozin, losartan, and lisinopril are the only drugs that have a proven benefit in patients with microalbuminuria. 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 receptor antagonist and prevents the deterioration of kidney function by reducing the activation of the macula densa. This is because blockade of the SGLT 2 receptor allows more Na+ and glucose to reach the JG apparatus thus reducing production of renin and subsequently the RAAS pathway. This reduces perfusion pressure in the glomerulus and reduces hyperfiltration injury. Losartan and Lisinopril are both drugs that modulate the RAAS pathway thus reducing the hyperfiltration injury. Thus these drugs can be added in the management of a patient with microalbuminuria based on their comorbidities to preserve kidney function. 

Amlodipine and Chlorthalidone offer no renoprotective effect so they will not be the first line in this patient.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for proteinuria with the gold standard test. What test was he likely advised?
questions.solution:
24-hour urine collection is the gold standard for quantification of protein excreted in the urine.

In this test, after the first voided morning sample is discarded, subsequent urine samples are collected in a container. Usually, a preservative is added to allow for later testing. This 24 hour sample is then evaluated to calculate the amount of protein excreted. Although spot urine protein to creatinine ratios are done in clinical practice, they have the disadvantage of being dependent on creatinine excretion which can vary. Hence, 24-hour urine protein studies are done in doubtful cases to quantify urine protein.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male patient comes with complaints of frothy urine and facial swelling since 3 weeks . He has had an on-and-off history of back and flank pain over the past year. Vitals are pulse 70bpm, BP 160/96 mmHg. An abdominal ultrasound is ordered. What is likely to be seen on USG?
questions.solution:
This patient complains of swelling in his face accompanied by frothy urine which likely indicates proteinuria. This combined with findings of on and off back and flank pain with high blood pressure raises suspicions of Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. That would manifest as cystic lesions in the kidneys on USG of the abdomen and pelvis.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males. 

Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include:

  • Flank/loin pain -  either due to haemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly uric acid stones)
  • Irregular upper quadrant renal mass
  • Proteinuria
  • Hematuria
  • Uremia
  • Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis)

Proteinuria is seen in patients with progressive disease and it is usually nephrotic range. Biopsies have shown the etiology to be focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and membranous nephropathy.

The most common extrarenal manifestation is hepatic cysts which are derived from the biliary epithelium. Other extra-renal manifestations of ADPKD:

  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Berry aneurysms (Rupture of cerebral aneurysms is an important cause of morbidity and The prevalence of intracranial aneurysms in patients with PKD is 40%.)
  • Colonic diverticula
  • Abdominal hernias
  • Mitral valve prolapse 

 Screening cerebral angiography is strongly considered in all patients with PKD and a family history of cerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due to multiple cysts. Nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD. 

Treatment includes

  • Surgical decompression is not a routine procedure performed in these patients. It may be required only in cases of very large cysts causing persistent pain and infected cysts.
  • Analgesics
  • Increased fluid intake 
    • Prevents renal stone formation
    • Reduces growth of cysts by suppressing ADH release
  • ACE inhibitors and ARBs
    • Blood pressure control 
    • Slowing of cyst growth
  • Tolvaptan (V2 receptor antagonist)
    • Reduce pain and slow the decline in renal function
  • Long-term dialysis
  • Renal transplant
    • Definitive management
    • Pre-transplant nephrectomy may be required in patients with very large polycystic kidneys

Other options: 

Option A: Fluid in the peritoneal cavity can occur in case of ascites. However, ascites is a late manifestation of prolonged proteinuria. This patient's flank pain with hypertension should raise suspicions of ADPKD.

Option B: Radiopaque masses in kidneys can be seen in nephrolithiasis. This presents with flank pain but it is colicky in nature and usually does not cause proteinuria enough to cause facial swelling. Hypertension is also not associated with nephrolithiasis.

Option D: Shrinkage of a kidney can occur in case of a unilateral renal artery stenosis which leads to reduced perfusion and reduction in the size. However, this isn't associated with proteinuria and flank pain.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma was started on a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that acts by inhibiting VEGF. He is now being evaluated for increasing protein excretion in his urine. Which of the following drugs was prescribed to the patient?

VEGF- Vascular endothelial growth factor
questions.solution:
Sunitinib is a small molecule, multi-targeted kinase antagonist/inhibitor and has been shown to have anti-tumor activity in renal cell carcinoma (RCC), gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs). Proteinuria is a common adverse effect of the drug. 

Pharmacology of sunitinib:

  • Molecular targets of sunitinib are c-Kit, VEGFR-2, PDGFR-β and Flt-3.
  • Sunitinib targets mutations in the RET gene.
  • The mechanisms of sunitinib’s action are:Inhibition of activated c-Kit and PDGFR in GIST
  • Inhibition of VEGFR in advanced RCC

Adverse effects:

  • Its specific adverse effects include neutropenia, diarrhea and fatigue.
  • Generally, the other common side effects of agents having anti-VEGFR activity are hypertension and proteinuria.
  • Rarely, they cause bleeding and clotting disorders, and perforation of scarred gastrointestinal lesions.
  • Hand-foot syndrome has also been noted in the use of these agents, with erythema and desquamation of distal extremities.

Administration: In advanced RCC and in adjuvant therapy, sunitinib is given orally, at a dose of 50mg per day, once daily, with or without food, for 4 weeks out of 6 (nine 6-week cycles in adjuvant therapy).

Uses:

  • In metastatic GIST, the main chemotherapeutic agent used is imatinib, which is a selective inhibitor of the c-kit tyrosine kinase. Patients whose tumors have become refractory to imatinib benefit from agents like sunitinib, which also inhibits c-kit tyrosine kinase.
  • It is now undergoing studies for efficacy in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Update:

  • The drug was previously approved for use by various regulatory bodies in 2006, for conditions like GIST and advanced RCC.
  • In 2017, sunitinib maleate was approved by the FDA for use as adjuvant therapy for patients at risk for recurrence of RCC after a kidney has been removed (nephrectomy).
  • This was based on a multi-center, international, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial among 615 patients with high risk of recurrent RCC following nephrectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Ramucirumab is a human IgG1 monoclonal antibody that targets VEGFR2, preventing VEGFR ligand binding and thereby reducing ligand-induced activity in endothelial cells. It is used in combination with docetaxel to treat patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Adverse effects include hypertension and diarrhea.

Option C: Aflibercept is a recombinant fusion protein that functions as a VEGF trap by sequestering VEGF using the VEGFR1-binding domain. It is used in treating metastatic colorectal cancer

Option D: Pembrolizumab is a humanized monoclonal IgG4κ isotype antibody that prevents the interaction between programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) and its ligands. It is used in the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, either before or after chemotherapy with platinum. It is also used in the treatment of melanoma, urothelial cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma and Hodgkin lymphoma. Serious adverse events include pneumonitis, colitis and hepatitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old with a past history of colon cancer with new onset massive proteinuria comes with abdominal pain. USG abdomen shows a thrombus in the left renal vein. What is likely to be present in this patient with regard to his underlying condition?

choices.text: Splitting of the glomerular basement membranes

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of massive proteinuria now presenting with a thrombus in his renal vein has developed renal vein thrombosis. The history of massive proteinuria suggests a nephrotic syndrome. Membranous nephropathy is the most commonly associated nephrotic syndrome associated with RVT. AntiPLA2R antibodies are associated with membranous nephropathy.

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in older adults, with a peak incidence in 30–50 years and a male: female ratio of 2:1. It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease. It can be primary (75% of cases) or secondary. Factors that can lead to secondary membranous nephropathy include:

  • Solid malignancies - colon, breast, lung.
  • Infection - Hepatitis B, Syphilis, Malaria, Schistosomiasis
  • Rheumatological disorders - Lupus, IgG4-related disease.

Light microscopy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall, due to deposition of immune complexes between the basement membrane and the overlying epithelial cells. Irregular spikes of basement membrane between these deposits are best seen with silver stains. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows diffuse granular deposits containing IgG and C3. Electron microscopy shows electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes.

This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated with renal vein thrombosis. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

Other options:
Option B: Elevated complement levels are not associated with any nephrotic syndrome reduced C3 levels are seen in post streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Option C: Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in Alport syndrome.

Option D: Immune complexes comprised of vitamin D is seen in IgA nephropathy. However, all these conditions are not commonly associated with RVT.

questions.text: You are analyzing urine samples for the presence of proteins. Which of the following conditions is associated with a high false negative rate on the urinary dipstick for the presence of protein?
questions.solution:
A urine dipstick is associated with a high rate of false negativity (up to 50% of cases) in multiple myeloma. This is due to the excreted proteinuria comprising of light chains which is not picked up by a urinary dipstick which is useful in cases of albuminuria. 

Urine dipstick examinations primarily detect albumin. A 24-hour urine protein quantitation and urine electrophoresis provide an estimate of total protein excretion, as well as the proportion of urine protein that is albumin versus monoclonal free light chains (M-protein).

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common symptom of multiple myeloma. Tumor cells release osteoclast activating factors (OAFs), which increase osteoclast activity and accelerate bone destruction. Furthermore, there is suppression of osteoblast activity to form new bone. Lysis of the bone leads to hypercalcemia. Patients with multiple myeloma also have an increased susceptibility to infections because of diffuse hypogammaglobulinemia (decreased production and increased destruction) of normal antibodies. 

Other important features of multiple myeloma include: 

  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic and normochromic anemia
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes
  • Elevated ESR
  • Normal alkaline phosphatase due to suppression of osteoblast activity.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein
  • Urinalysis shows free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence-Jones proteins)

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma include:

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically: (CRAB features)Hypercalcemia:
    • Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >2 g/dL below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET).
    • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
      • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥ 60%
      • Serum involved / uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater.
      • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

All the other options are conditions which cause albumin to be excreted, hence they will lead to a positive urine dipstick.

questions.text: A patient with acyclovir resistant CMV retinitis on treatment with an IV drug is being evaluated for a positive diptick protein test. There are also crystals seen in his urine on microscopy. What is the likely drug he was started on?
questions.solution:
This patient with acyclovir-resistant CMV retinitis now presenting with crystals in his urine with proteinuria has been likely started on Foscarnet. 80% of the foscarnet is usually excreted unchanged in the urine and is what leads to the nephrotoxic effect. This can be prevented by giving plenty of hydration.

Foscarnet is an antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV. Foscarnet is an inorganic pyrophosphate analog. It does not require activation by viral thymidine kinase for antiviral activity. It inhibits viral nucleic acid synthesis by directly inhibiting HSV DNA polymerase and HIV reverse transcriptase.

Foscarnet is used to treat acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus (genital herpes) and varicella-zoster virus infections and ganciclovir-resistant cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It is also used as an alternative agent in CMV retinitis in AIDS, and CMV viremia in bone marrow transplant recipients.

Common side effects of foscarnet include nephrotoxicity and hypocalcemia.

Foscarnet is mainly excreted by the kidneys. Therefore, dose reduction is necessary for renal impairment to avoid the accumulation of the drug and associated toxicity.

Other options:

Option A: Tenofovir is a reverse transcriptase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of viral RNA into proviral DNA. It helps to prevent infection of susceptible cells but does not eradicate the virus from cells that are integrated with proviral DNA. It is active against HIV 1, 2, and HBV.

Option C: Amphotericin B is a broad-spectrum antifungal. It binds to ergosterol in the fungal membrane and forms pores or channels in the fungal cell membrane. This allows the leakage of cytosolic molecules and ions, leading to a loss of membrane integrity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the casualty due to reduced urination. A Foley catheter is placed. The urine analysis reveals proteinuria. Her BP was found to be 200/100 mmHg. She has a history of scleroderma. Which of the following drugs will be the mainstay in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of proteinuria, accelerated hypertension, and oliguria along with a past history of scleroderma is suggestive of a scleroderma renal crisis. ACE inhibitors like captopril are the first line drugs in the management of a scleroderma renal crisis.

Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency characterized by acute onset malignant hypertension and kidney failure, usually in the absence of previous evidence of significant kidney disease. The use of steroids is associated with an increased risk of scleroderma renal crisis.

Clinical features of scleroderma renal crisis are:

  • Accelerated hypertension - headache, vomiting, blurring of vision, hypertensive retinopathy, and hypertensive encephalopathy.
  • Acute kidney injury - oliguria, mild proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, renal failure.
  • Pulmonary edema, congestive heart failure.
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes), thrombocytopenia.

Risk factors for scleroderma renal crisis include African-American race, male sex, and diffuse or progressive skin involvement. Up to 50% of patients with scleroderma renal crisis have anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, whereas patients with anti-centromere antibodies appear to be protected from this complication.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) (Option 1) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis. 
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody (Option 2)- usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (Option 2)
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody (Option 4)- usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency and should be treated with angiotensin II receptor blockers, calcium channel blockers, and direct renin inhibitors. Glucocorticoids should be used at a low dose only when necessary.

questions.text: A patient with proteinuria is being evaluated. A CT scan shows a thrombus in the inferior vena cava. What is the likely mechanism of proteinuria?
questions.solution:
This patient with a finding of proteinuria is found to have a thrombus in the inferior vena cava. This leads to an increased capillary hydrostatic pressure downstream from the renal vein which leads to hyperfiltration and thus proteinuria. 

Starling's forces are what determine the rate of filtration along a capillary. These forces are represented as:

Fluid movement = k [(Pc− Pi) − (πc− πi)]

where, k = capillary filtration coefficient

Pc = capillary hydrostatic pressure

Pi = interstitial hydrostatic pressure

πc = capillary colloid osmotic pressure

πi = interstitial colloid osmotic pressure

In this scenario, this patient with a thrombus in the IVC has increased Pc which leads to increased fluid movements into the kidney tubules. This hyperfiltration can lead to proteinuria if the force is large enough to cause injury to the tubular cells. Similar findings are seen in a patient with hypertension who will also have hyperfiltration injury leading to proteinuria.

questions.text: A patient post hepatic transplant requires immunosuppression. He has proteinuria on the urine dipstick. Which of the following drugs is safe to use in his case?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of hepatic transplantation requires immunosuppression. Since he is a known case of renal disease with proteinuria, he requires a drug that has a low incidence of nephrotoxicity. Mycophenolate mofetil is the drug of choice for him.

Mycophenolate mofetil is a prodrug that is rapidly converted to mycophenolic acid.

It is a selective, non-competitive, reversible inhibitor of inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), an important enzyme in the de novo pathway of guanine nucleotide synthesis.

It is a useful immunosuppressive in cases where cyclosporine or tacrolimus are not tolerated. It is used for the prevention of organ transplant rejection.

Other options:

Sirolimus can cause worsening proteinuria in existing kidney disease and is hence contraindicated in this patient. 

Cyclosporin and tacrolimus are both nephrotoxic and are not indicated for a known case of kidney dysfuntion.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatic heart disease comes with complaints of reduced urination. Urine analysis reveals proteinuria and hematuria. A renal biopsy shows crescent formation, with a few embolic and septic abscesses. Which of the following primary conditions could have led to his renal findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with rheumatic heart disease (indicating a damaged heart valve) now presents with oliguria, proteinuria, and hematuria. The biopsy findings of crescents and abscesses make septic emboli the likely cause. Subacute bacterial endocarditis is most likely associated with endocarditis-associated glomerulonephritis. 

Endocarditis-associated glomerulonephritis is mostly associated with subacute bacterial endocarditis that has gone untreated for a long time as it allows for the formation of antigen-antibody complexes. Acute bacterial endocarditis on the other hand is picked up clinically and is usually treated aggressively thus not allowing for the kidney disease to progress. 

Patients commonly present with oliguria, acute kidney injury or rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Grossly, the kidney will show a flea-bitten appearance with multiple abscesses. Biopsy shows crescents. Immunofluorescence shows IgM, IgG, and C3.

Treatment is treating the underlying endocarditis, and monitoring the patient for improvement in kidney function. 

Other Options:

Option A: Henoch-schonlein purpura usually has an accompanying palpable purpura with glomerulonephritis. It is also not associated with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Option C: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia can occur in cases of valve replacements where the valve malfunctions leading to shearing and rupture of RBCs. This can present with findings of proteinuria and hematuria but the presence of crescents on biopsy and a lack of history of valve replacement makes endocrditis likely.

Option D:  Sickle cell disease causes renal papillary necrosis which presents with frank hematuria and progressively declining renal function. The additional finding of septic emboli makes an infective cause more likely.

questions.text: In which of the following cases with proteinuria is renal biopsy not indicated?

choices.text: A patient with urine protein of 300 mg/day
A patient with hematuria and proteinuria
A patient with unexplained acute kidney injury

questions.solution:
Isolated proteinuria of less than 500 mg/day is a contraindication to renal biopsy since the risks outweigh the benefits. This range of proteinuria is usually a mild disease or can be a consequence of normal aging. 

Indications of kidney biopsy:

  1. Nephrotic syndrome with no apparent cause
  2. Nephritic syndrome to identify the cause to guide further management
  3. Unexplained acute kidney injury

Contraindications of kidney biopsy:

  1. Non-nephrotic range proteinuria(<500mg/day) with no hematuria as their prognosis is good and usually have no specialised treatment
  2. Single kidney is a a relative contraindication
  3. Bleeding diathesis
  4. Hydronephrosis
  5. Solitary native kidney

Pregnancy as such is not a contraindication for renal biopsy and is decided on a case to case basis.

questions.text: A marathon runner is brought in because of reduced urination 8 hours after a 30 km marathon on a sunny day. Urine analysis shows a dark yellow color, creatinine 0.8 mg/dl, urine protein ++, and blood negative. His BP is 100/60 mmHg. What is the cause of his urinary protein findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting 8 hours after a marathon with only proteinuria with other renal parameters within normal limits is likely a case of isolated proteinuria due to strenuous exercise which leads to a transient increase in the glomerular permeability. This condition is self-resolving and requires no further management except for adequate hydration. 

Other options:

Option B: Acute kidney injury presents with an increase in creatinine as a symptom which is not present in this patient.

Option C: Rhabdomyolysis presents with myoglobin in the urine which can cause a positive test in the urine dipstick for blood. Here it is negative making rhabdomyolysis unlikely. 

Option D: Dehydration can cause concentration of the blood components but it will not cause proteinuria.

questions.text: A young primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted since her BP was 150/90 mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. All the following will be included in the diagnostic criteria of pre-eclampsia, except ________.
questions.solution:
A platelet count of 1.5 lakh/cu.mm is not a criterion to diagnose pre-eclampsia.

Pre-eclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery. It is characterized by blood pressure of >140/90 mmHg on two occasions 4 hours apart with proteinuria or signs of end-organ damage.

Criteria to diagnose pre-eclampsia:

  • Proteinuria of ≥ 300 mg (0.3 g) in 24 hours or urine protein:creatinine ratio of ≥0.3
  • Platelet count of <1 lakh/cu.mm
  • Serum creatinine level of >1.1 mg/dL
  • Serum transaminase levels twice the normal concentration
  • Headache, visual disturbances, or epigastric pain
  • Pulmonary edema

Clinical types of pre-eclampsia:

  • Nonsevere pre-eclampsia: Blood pressure >140/90 mmHg but <160/110 mmHg without significant proteinuria
  • Severe pre-eclampsia: Persistent increase of systolic blood pressure above 160 mmHg or diastolic above 110 mmHg with any of the following, proteinuria, oliguria (<400 mL in 24 hours), platelet count <1 lakh/cu.mm, serum creatinine level of >1.1 mg/dL, persistent severe epigastric pain, marked elevation of liver enzyme levels, cerebral (convulsions) or visual disturbances, intrauterine growth restriction of the fetus, and pulmonary edema.

Complications of pre-eclampsia:

  • Eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Preterm labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Shock
  • Sepsis

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with edema, oliguria, and frothy urine. He has no history of similar complaints. His urine was positive for 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs/WBCs, and no casts. His serum albumin was 2.4 gm/dL and serum creatinine was 0.5 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of minimal change disease.

It most frequently manifests between the ages of 2 and 6 years. Edema is typically seen in children and is first noticed in the lower extremities and around the eyes. The absence of hypertension and extensive hematuria are key indicators of minimal change disease.

A urinalysis reveals 3+ or 4+ proteinuria. A protein: creatinine ratio of > 2.0 is required in spot urine. The level of serum creatinine is typically normal, but it may be unusually elevated if the intravascular volume contracts and reduces renal perfusion. The serum albumin concentration is less than 2.5 g/dL, and the levels of triglycerides and cholesterol are high. The levels of serum complement are normal. If the patient meets the typical clinical profile of MCNS, a kidney biopsy is not generally carried out.

Other options:

Option A: The typical sign of IgA nephropathy is episodic hematuria linked to the deposition of IgA in the mesangium. One of the most prevalent types of glomerulonephritis in the globe is IgA nephropathy. Recurrent episodes of macroscopic hematuria during or right after an upper respiratory infection, frequently accompanied by proteinuria, and persistent asymptomatic microscopic hematuria is the two most typical manifestations of IgA nephropathy. 

Option C: Membranous nephropathy peaks between the ages of 30 and 50, with a male-to-female ratio of 2:1. It is the most frequent cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly and is rare in children. MGN is linked to malignancy, infection, rheumatic disorders such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, IgG4 diseases, or drug exposure. A worse prognosis is linked to the male gender, advanced age, hypertension, and the continuation of nephrotic-range proteinuria.

Option D: Interstitial nephritis is indicated by the presence of white blood cells and white blood cell casts along with low-grade hematuria and proteinuria. Some children with drug-induced tubulointerstitial nephritis may have eosinophils in their urine.
